title: There Can Be No Glory Without Honor
body:
At the end of every season, we see the same arguments about how punishing people with loss of season rewards if they're below Honor 2 at that time is unfair considering that people who get punished earlier in the season have an opportunity to work their way back into good standing. It's gotten so bad that Riot is making a [one-time change to how this is handled](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/TGYs0hwO-2018-end-of-season-rewards-and-honor).

I would argue that's still unfair, especially when you consider that end-of-season and the period between seasons tend to be really chaotic and tense. You're asking people to be on significantly better than average behavior at the time when it's most difficult to keep your cool. Add in the stress of this one-time deal and things are going to be rough.

My solution would be that you earn whatever rewards you're entitled to at the end of season, but _**you can't wear any of that flair at ANY TIME you're below Honor 2**_. I feel this would be an excellent incentive for improvement and would feel more even-handed than the current system. In fact, having a ceremony where you regain all that content would probably feel amazing.

EDITED FOR CLARITY: Under my proposal, you would "lose" all ranked rewards for all seasons whenever you dipped below Honor 2. You would probably gain a quest to get to Honor 2 and regaining that content would be the reward. This would be a relatively easy thing to add to the client, at least in my opinion.

Sure it would. They effectively don't have the skin until they reach back up to honor 2.

But I'd go further with it, and lock it out until you reach honor 4. So they'd still have the skin they rightfully earned by being a cooperative, effective teammate (which actually improves the community), but not get to use it for pretty much the whole season.

That would cut off those that do some ranked and get up, which doesnt always take a lot of games... and pretty much make it so that even if they are doing good and being helpful, they still are not able to use it. (If its brought to honor 4)

They also made the change so that people would behave more. Which works on paper but if someone is usually nice and helpful, honor 5 and good and never tilting, they could be in diamond or master or something.... then they argue with someone in game once and BOOM they lose out on everything. That is where the issue comes.

Its pretty much the same with getting locked out of rewards for a month or longer just because of it. It makes you feel even worse when you get hardly any key fragments on top of all that.

Yes, it is supposed to feel like a punishment. However, for a minor thing like chat restrict, should the punishment REALLY be that harsh? Yes, punishment is required, its a show of "this behavior is not acceptable". But even locking people out from being able to USE the rewards feels almost as bad as not getting them in the first place.

I would also add that if you ever are punished for *game play* related punishments (inting, boosting, scripting, and the like), that you still lose the opportunity to earn rewards for the rest of that season. I can agree that chat related behavior incidents could warrant a system described above, but game play misbehavior is reprehensible enough to warrant a much harsher punishment.

Many of the OPs I have seen in PB have asked for chat behavior punishments to be less-harsh. Also, many of the frequent posters I have seen disagree with much leniency, myself included. I feel this is a good approach toward a middle ground, where people who have hit near the top of the "punishment volcano" have a significant enough deterrent, but it is not a crippling burden.

With my addendum above, I feel it also keeps the significant punishment necessary as a deterrent for game play related punishments.

Thoughts?

> [{quoted}](name=Ulanopo,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=WdU7vaWI,comment-id=,timestamp=2018-11-17T01:17:53.842+0000)

> significantly better than average behavior

Behavior that avoids a ban is actually firmly average. Penalties are the exception, not the rule.

Moving the goalposts reduces clarity and consistency. If Riot now believes that the punishment system was too harsh, they can improve the rules for next season. There was no need to make a mockery of this season's rules just to accommodate people who tripped at the finish line (because they were busy flipping someone the bird).

I think we're probably in agreement about average behavior, but talking past each other in a way. Yes, neutral behavior is _average_, but the kind of behavior that would be required to gain honor in a highly restricted time frame would not be. You would either have to carry really hard (as there are always people who grant honor for performance) or be positive in a way that didn't feel like pandering. Neither of those things are easy.

As to "tripping at the finish line", there have been some suggestions that the end-of-season loss of ranked rewards actually exists to try and rein in the worst behavior, but I'd be very curious to see the numbers on behavior during this period. I suspect, though certainly have no way of confirming, that the way this is handled is more an artifact of "how things have always been done" rather than anything else.

I reread your post a few times to determine whether you were talking about behavior in general or behavior after receiving a punishment late in the season, and I read it as the former, but I guess it was the latter. However, the key factor in gaining Honor isn't exemplary behavior; it's time. The system encourages consistent positive behavior, not spurts of power-farming Honor.

I'm in full agreement with you that the Honor system and the way it interacts with ranked rewards could use significant work. However, "Whose Lane Is It Anyway" in the middle of the season was an insulting meme because it made good gameplay decisions indistinguishable from bad gameplay decisions. Retroactively changing Honor/reward expectations just as the season ends and rewards were to have been calculated may make the same mess out of player behavior.

> My solution would be that you earn whatever rewards you're entitled to at the end of season, but you can't wear any of that flair unless you're at least Honor 2.

This is fucking brilliant. It encourages players to strife into reforming when they get their end of season rewards. I always felt that "You're never getting them if you're considered a bad sport" was a bit over the top. 

+1

One the one hand I think this is an over all great idea, but on the other hand you're not really losing anything of value then when you become dishonorable, but then again bronze and silver players aren't really losing anything with the current system either and it feels kinda dumb that only the top 25% are really being punished for bad behaviour.
So yeah I'm entirely in favor of this.
I'm only here for the Assemble the Legion art. Love that card!
Boros Legion OP
I'm finally running a 5e game now that the Ravnica book is out, so they were on my mind.

Or, and hear me out on this one, riot could do away with this whole notion that honor should be tied to ranked rewards. Instead they could focus on providing honorable players with different rewards for being honorable. Hell, they could even introduce an honorable skin line for some of the more mild-mannered champions or something of that sort.

If the whole reasoning behind locking ranked rewards behind honor levels is to reduce toxicity, then what is the point of the punishment system and this new IFS? This thing really ramped up in punishment frequency this year, so why not let the punishment system of chat restrictions escalating into suspensions play out as it is designed to? Maybe instead of threatening players with the loss of rewards riot should be looking to give unique rewards to those who consistently display the most positive attitudes, because from what I've seen of this IFS, it is more than capable of punishing mild to extreme toxicity accordingly. Why pressure players that are already at risk of losing their accounts because of bad behavior, with even more restrictions and deadlines for displaying reform? 

Anyways, that's just my 2 cents on this matter. Thoughts?
